hints_html: Can you separate the variables \(L\) and \(t\)?
hints_latex: Can you separate the variables $L$ and $t$?
hints_raw: Can you separate the variables <math>L</math> and <math>t</math>?
sols_html:
Beginning with the equation

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dL}{dt} = kL^2\ln t\end{aligned}\]

we separate the variables \(L\) and \(t\) to obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{L^2}dL = k \ln t \,dt\end{aligned}\]

If we then integrate both sides of this equation (ignoring the constant of integration in the first case) we find that

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{1}{L^2}dL = -\frac{1}{L}\end{aligned}\]

and using integration by parts we find that

\[\begin{aligned} \int k \ln t \, dt = k (t \ln t - t) + C\end{aligned}\]

and so if we set the two of these equal to each other we find that

\[\begin{aligned} -\frac{1}{L} = k(t \ln t - t) + C\end{aligned}\]

If we solve for \(L\) we find

\[\begin{aligned} L = - \frac{1}{k(t \ln t - t) + C}\end{aligned}\]

Since \(L(1) = 1\) it follows that \(C = k - 1\) and so

\[\begin{aligned} L(t) = -\frac{1}{k(t\ln t - t) + k - 1}\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
Beginning with the equation

:<math> \frac{dL}{dt} = kL^2\ln t </math>

we separate the variables <math>L</math> and <math>t</math> to obtain

:<math> \frac{1}{L^2}dL = k \ln t \,dt</math>

If we then integrate both sides of this equation (ignoring the constant of integration in the first case) we find that

:<math> \int \frac{1}{L^2}dL = -\frac{1}{L}</math>

and using integration by parts we find that

:<math> \int k \ln t \, dt =  k (t \ln t - t) + C</math>

and so if we set the two of these equal to each other we find that

:<math> -\frac{1}{L} = k(t \ln t - t) + C </math>

If we solve for <math>L</math> we find

:<math> L = - \frac{1}{k(t \ln t - t) + C}</math>

Since <math>L(1) = 1</math> it follows that <math> C = k - 1</math> and so

:<math> L(t) = -\frac{1}{k(t\ln t - t) + k - 1}</math>
statement_html:
Find the solution of the differential equation

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dL}{dt}=kL^{2}\ln t\end{aligned}\]

that satisfies \(L(1)=1\). Here, \(k\) is a constant that will appear in your final answer.
statement_raw:
Find the solution of the differential equation

:<math> \frac{dL}{dt}=kL^{2}\ln t </math>

that satisfies <math> L(1)=1 </math>. Here, <math>k</math> is a constant that will appear in your final answer.
